_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Farmers cooperative of Winside Nebraska coplies with ANSI K-61-1 requirements for anhydrous ammmoinia storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal state and local laws.  We are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of NH3. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Winside Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.

The primary purpose of this facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to the agriculture sector. Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application through sales to farmers.  Access to the site is resticted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personel, and authorized contractors.  The maximum intended inventory of our ammonia storage tank, and nurse tanks is 315,000 lbs.

We used RMP Comp to determine the worst case scenario release at our facility. Failure of our storage tank when filled to the greatest amount would have offsite consequences. We have check valves and relief valves along with manual shutoff to help reduce the chance of failures.

This facility complies with EPAs Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of Safety Requrements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61-1 and the stadards of OSHA,29 CFR 1901.111 Storage and Handling of Anydrous Ammonia.

We have never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injury, property or enviromental damage, evacuation or sheltering in place.We have not had a release with offsite cosequences in the past 5 years.

In the event of an emergency in volving our anhydrous ammonia system it is our policy to notify the Winside Fire Department, and request that they respond to the emergency. We have discussed this policy with the fire department and they have inspected our system.

Safety improvement is an ongoing process at our facility.  Periodic evaluatio

ns are preformed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.

The Farmers Cooperative has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements. We have assigned a qualified person that has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements. Randy Jensen is this qualified person and is responsible for the development, implemntation, and integration of the risk management program elements.

Joan Liermann has the overall authority for the following elements:
     Safety Information
     Hazard Review
     Operation Procedures
     Training
     Maitenance
     Compliance Audits
     Accident Investigations
